qas.question: Who described post-punk as "a more adventurous and arty form of punk"?
Who described post-punk as  "less a genre of music than a space of possibility"?
Who said "so multifarious that only the broadest use of the term is possible" with regards to post-punk?
Who does music critic Stephen Thomas Erlewine work for?
What as the blanket term "post-punk" been the target of?
What organization is Stephen Thomas Erlewine associated with?
What have some people suggested post-punk doesn't have, instead being more about approaches and sensibilities?
Why type of scholar is music journalist Simon Reynolds?
Why is only the broadest use of genre possible when trying to categorize what actually defines post-punk?
Who described post-punk as "a less adventutous and arty form of punk"
What did Nicholas Lezard say post-punk was more of?
What did Simon Reynold describe as multifarious?
Who does the music critic Nicholas Lezard work for?
What is Stephen Thomas Erlwine a scholar of?
What has the term "post-punk" never been the focus of?
Who suggested that post-punk be conceived as "more a genre of music than a space of possibility"?
Who never cared about the categorization of post-punk as a genre?

context: The scope of the term "post-punk" has been subject to <a4_0><b14_0>controversy<b14_0/><a4_0/>. While some critics, such as <a3_0><a5_0><b9_0><b12_0>AllMusic<a5_0/><a3_0/>'s<b12_0/> <a0_0><b15_0>Stephen Thomas Erlewine<b15_0/><b9_0/><a0_0/>, have employed the term "post-punk" to denote "a more adventurous and arty form of punk", others have suggested it pertains to a set of artistic sensibilities and approaches rather than any <a6_0>unifying style<a6_0/>. Music journalist and <a7_0><b11_0><b13_0>post-punk<b13_0/><b11_0/><a7_0/> scholar <a1_0><b16_0>Simon Reynolds<b16_0/><a1_0/> has advocated that post-punk be conceived as "less a genre of music than <b10_0>a space of possibility<b10_0/>", suggesting that "what unites all this activity is a set of open-ended imperatives: innovation; willful oddness; the willful jettisoning of all things precedented or 'rock'n'roll'". <a2_0><b17_0>Nicholas Lezard<b17_0/><a2_0/>, problematizing the categorization of post-punk as a genre, described the movement as "so <a8_0>multifarious<a8_0/> that only the broadest use of the term is possible".
